intro: Podolepis mitchellii, commonly known as Mitchell's podolepis, is a flowering plant species native to the southern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and thrives in full sun. Its botanical features include a slender, branched stem and white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. It is often found in open woodlands and is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
